Award.AwardTitle: Conference: New Advances in Probing Cell-Extracellular Matrix Interactions; Berlin, Germany; October 21 - 22, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of the secrets to life lie outside the cell. The extracellular matrix (ECM), consisting of primarily proteins supports the cells within a tissue. While the ECM has long been viewed as a static "home" for cells, we are starting to understand how the stiffness of the extracellular matrix changes cell activities in ways that are similar to how dissolved signaling molecules control cell behavior. In other words, the ECM helps determine what the cell does during development of a baby, and during adulthood, wound healing, and cancer invasion. Support from this grant for the conference "New Advances in Probing Cell-Extracellular Matrix Interactions; Berlin, Germany; October 21 - 22, 2016" will enable young investigators to meet senior scientists and to understand technologies at the cutting edge of the field.

Recent progress in cell mechanotransduction research has been facilitated by advances of experimental tools. Microtechnologies have enabled the design and fabrication of controlled physical microenvironments for the study and measurement of cell-ECM interactions. Advances in engineered biomaterials have allowed researchers to develop synthetic ECMs that mimic tissue microenvironments and investigate the impact of altered physicochemical properties on various cellular processes. Finally, advanced imaging and spectroscopy techniques have facilitated the visualization of the complex interaction between cells and ECM in vitro and in living tissues. This meeting will highlight the application of recent innovations in these technologies to probing cell-ECM interactions with an aim to inspire new combinatorial experiments from the interaction of these sub-disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cell-extracellular matrix interactions have been found to play a key in many biological processes in development, homeostasis and regeneration, and diseases such as cancer, and has therefore emerged as an important topic of study for understanding these processes and in designing new therapeutic approaches. The nature of research in this field is remarkably interdisciplinary, as key advances have been made by researchers from a broad variety of backgrounds, including those with training in molecular and cell biology, chemistry, chemical engineering, bioengineering, mechanical engineering, materials science, and biophysics. Recent progress in this area has been facilitated by advances of experimental tools in microtechnologies, biomaterials, and imaging.  Due to this interdisciplinary nature, progress in this field has not been adequately covered by the traditional discipline focused conferences. Further, there have been limited interactions between the community of researchers in in this field in the United States and in Europe. We organized a conference entitled, New Advances in Probing Cell-Extracellular Matrix Interactions, to address this gap. This conference took place in Berlin, Germany; October 21 - 22, 2016. The conference brought together 80 scientists in the field, including some of the leading experts. The NSF grant supported the participation of junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students, giving them the opportunity to present their research to the community and network with the international group of expert scientists. Interactions at this conference are likely to have led to a number of new collaborations and research ideas, and we anticipate that these new collaborations and ideas will result in impactful research in this field. Further, this conference motivated the publication of a review article published in Integrative Biology by Allen Liu, Ovijit Chaudhuri, and Sapun Parekh in 2017, which highlighted some of the emerging trends of research in this area discussed at the conference.
